natural problem: Coach Grunt is preparing the 5-person starting lineup for his basketball team, the Grunters.  There are 12 players on the team.  Two of them, Ace and Zeppo, are league All-Stars, so they'll definitely be in the starting lineup.  How many different starting lineups are possible?  (The order of the players in a basketball lineup doesn't matter.)
natural solution: Coach Grunt has to choose 3 players from the 10 players that are remaining after Ace and Zeppo have been placed in the lineup. The order in which the players are chosen doesn't matter, so the answer is $$ \binom{10}{3} = \frac{10 \times 9 \times 8}{3 \times 2 \times 1} = \boxed{120}.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes total_players all_stars starting_lineup_size :: nat
assumes h0 : "total_players = 12"
and h1 : "all_stars = 2"
and h2 : "starting_lineup_size = 5"
and h3 : "all_stars \<le> starting_lineup_size"
shows  "card (possible_starting_lineups total_players all_stars starting_lineup_size) = 120"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Coach Grunt is preparing the 5-person starting lineup for his basketball team, the Grunters.  There are 12 players on the team.  Two of them, Ace and Zeppo, are league All-Stars, so they'll definitely be in the starting lineup.  How many different starting lineups are possible?  (The order of the players in a basketball lineup doesn't matter.) The final Answer is 120
 ### Proof
 Coach Grunt has to choose 3 players from the 10 players that are remaining after Ace and Zeppo have been placed in the lineup. The order in which the players are chosen doesn't matter, so the answer is $$ \binom{10}{3} = \frac{10 \times 9 \times 8}{3 \times 2 \times 1} = \boxed{120}.
 $$
 *)

theorem
fixes total_players all_stars starting_lineup_size :: nat
assumes h0 : "total_players = 12"
and h1 : "all_stars = 2"
and h2 : "starting_lineup_size = 5"
and h3 : "all_stars \<le> starting_lineup_size"
shows  "card (possible_starting_lineups total_players all_stars starting_lineup_size) = 120"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: In a basketball team with 12 players, there are 2 all-star players. A starting lineup consists of 5 players, and the lineup must include at least 2 all-star players. How many different possible starting lineups can be formed? The final answer is 120.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n k allStars :: nat and C :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "n = 12"
and h1 : "k = 5"
and h2 : "allStars = 2"
and h3 : "C n k = fact n div (fact k * fact (n - k))"
shows  "C (n - allStars) (k - allStars) = 120"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Coach Grunt is preparing the 5-person starting lineup for his basketball team, the Grunters.  There are 12 players on the team.  Two of them, Ace and Zeppo, are league All-Stars, so they'll definitely be in the starting lineup.  How many different starting lineups are possible?  (The order of the players in a basketball lineup doesn't matter.) The final Answer is 120
 ### Proof
 Coach Grunt has to choose 3 players from the 10 players that are remaining after Ace and Zeppo have been placed in the lineup. The order in which the players are chosen doesn't matter, so the answer is $$ \binom{10}{3} = \frac{10 \times 9 \times 8}{3 \times 2 \times 1} = \boxed{120}.
 $$
 *)

theorem
fixes n k allStars :: nat and C :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "n = 12"
and h1 : "k = 5"
and h2 : "allStars = 2"
and h3 : "C n k = fact n div (fact k * fact (n - k))"
shows  "C (n - allStars) (k - allStars) = 120"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: In a group of 12 people, you want to choose 5 to form a team. However, there are 2 all-stars who must be included on the team. How many different ways are there to choose the remaining members of the team? The final answer is 120.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n k a z :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 12"
and h1 : "k = 5"
and h2 : "a = 1"
and h3 : "z = 1"
and h4 : "k = a + z + 3"
shows  "n choose k = 120"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Coach Grunt is preparing the 5-person starting lineup for his basketball team, the Grunters.  There are 12 players on the team.  Two of them, Ace and Zeppo, are league All-Stars, so they'll definitely be in the starting lineup.  How many different starting lineups are possible?  (The order of the players in a basketball lineup doesn't matter.) The final Answer is 120
 ### Proof
 Coach Grunt has to choose 3 players from the 10 players that are remaining after Ace and Zeppo have been placed in the lineup. The order in which the players are chosen doesn't matter, so the answer is $$ \binom{10}{3} = \frac{10 \times 9 \times 8}{3 \times 2 \times 1} = \boxed{120}.
 $$
 *)

theorem
fixes n k a z :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 12"
and h1 : "k = 5"
and h2 : "a = 1"
and h3 : "z = 1"
and h4 : "k = a + z + 3"
shows  "n choose k = 120"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Find the number of ways to choose 5 items from a set of 12 items, i.e., calculate the binomial coefficient "12 choose 5". The final answer is 120.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes nCr :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n k. nCr n k = fact n div (fact k * fact (n-k))"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. fact n = (if n = 0 then 1 else n * fact (n - 1))"
and h2 : "Ace \<noteq> Zeppo"
and h3 : "Ace \<in> set_of_players"
and h4 : "Zeppo \<in> set_of_players"
and h5 : "card set_of_players = 12"
and h6 : "card (set_of_players - {Ace, Zeppo}) = 10"
shows  "nCr 10 3 = 120"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Coach Grunt is preparing the 5-person starting lineup for his basketball team, the Grunters.  There are 12 players on the team.  Two of them, Ace and Zeppo, are league All-Stars, so they'll definitely be in the starting lineup.  How many different starting lineups are possible?  (The order of the players in a basketball lineup doesn't matter.) The final Answer is 120
 ### Proof
 Coach Grunt has to choose 3 players from the 10 players that are remaining after Ace and Zeppo have been placed in the lineup. The order in which the players are chosen doesn't matter, so the answer is $$ \binom{10}{3} = \frac{10 \times 9 \times 8}{3 \times 2 \times 1} = \boxed{120}.
 $$
 *)

theorem
fixes nCr :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n k. nCr n k = fact n div (fact k * fact (n-k))"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. fact n = (if n = 0 then 1 else n * fact (n - 1))"
and h2 : "Ace \<noteq> Zeppo"
and h3 : "Ace \<in> set_of_players"
and h4 : "Zeppo \<in> set_of_players"
and h5 : "card set_of_players = 12"
and h6 : "card (set_of_players - {Ace, Zeppo}) = 10"
shows  "nCr 10 3 = 120"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: In a group of 12 players, including Ace and Zeppo, how many ways can we choose a team of 3 players without including Ace and Zeppo? The final answer is 120.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes num_players num_starters num_all_stars :: nat
assumes h0 : "num_players = 12"
and h1 : "num_starters = 5"
and h2 : "num_all_stars = 2"
shows  "n_choose_k (num_players - num_all_stars) (num_starters - num_all_stars) = 120"
where "n_choose_k n k = fact n div (fact k * fact (n - k))"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Coach Grunt is preparing the 5-person starting lineup for his basketball team, the Grunters.  There are 12 players on the team.  Two of them, Ace and Zeppo, are league All-Stars, so they'll definitely be in the starting lineup.  How many different starting lineups are possible?  (The order of the players in a basketball lineup doesn't matter.) The final Answer is 120
 ### Proof
 Coach Grunt has to choose 3 players from the 10 players that are remaining after Ace and Zeppo have been placed in the lineup. The order in which the players are chosen doesn't matter, so the answer is $$ \binom{10}{3} = \frac{10 \times 9 \times 8}{3 \times 2 \times 1} = \boxed{120}.
 $$
 *)

theorem
fixes num_players num_starters num_all_stars :: nat
assumes h0 : "num_players = 12"
and h1 : "num_starters = 5"
and h2 : "num_all_stars = 2"
shows  "n_choose_k (num_players - num_all_stars) (num_starters - num_all_stars) = 120"
where "n_choose_k n k = fact n div (fact k * fact (n - k))"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: A basketball team has 12 players, with 5 of them being starters and 2 of them being all-stars. How many different ways can the coach choose the remaining 3 starters from the non-all-star players? The final answer is 120.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n k allstars others :: nat
assumes h0 : "allstars = 2"
and h1 : "others = 12 - allstars"
and h2 : "n = allstars + others"
and h3 : "k = 5 - allstars"
shows  "n choose k = 120"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Coach Grunt is preparing the 5-person starting lineup for his basketball team, the Grunters.  There are 12 players on the team.  Two of them, Ace and Zeppo, are league All-Stars, so they'll definitely be in the starting lineup.  How many different starting lineups are possible?  (The order of the players in a basketball lineup doesn't matter.) The final Answer is 120
 ### Proof
 Coach Grunt has to choose 3 players from the 10 players that are remaining after Ace and Zeppo have been placed in the lineup. The order in which the players are chosen doesn't matter, so the answer is $$ \binom{10}{3} = \frac{10 \times 9 \times 8}{3 \times 2 \times 1} = \boxed{120}.
 $$
 *)

theorem
fixes n k allstars others :: nat
assumes h0 : "allstars = 2"
and h1 : "others = 12 - allstars"
and h2 : "n = allstars + others"
and h3 : "k = 5 - allstars"
shows  "n choose k = 120"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: There are 2 all-star players and 10 other players on a basketball team. In how many ways can a coach choose a lineup of 5 players that includes at least 1 all-star player? The final answer is 120.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n k :: nat and starting_lineup :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "n = 12"
and h1 : "k = 5"
and h2 : "Ace \<in> starting_lineup"
and h3 : "Zeppo \<in> starting_lineup"
and h4 : "card starting_lineup = k"
and h5 : "starting_lineup \<subseteq> {1..n}"
shows  "card {S. S \<subseteq> {1..n} - {Ace, Zeppo} \<and> card S = k - 2} = 120"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Coach Grunt is preparing the 5-person starting lineup for his basketball team, the Grunters.  There are 12 players on the team.  Two of them, Ace and Zeppo, are league All-Stars, so they'll definitely be in the starting lineup.  How many different starting lineups are possible?  (The order of the players in a basketball lineup doesn't matter.) The final Answer is 120
 ### Proof
 Coach Grunt has to choose 3 players from the 10 players that are remaining after Ace and Zeppo have been placed in the lineup. The order in which the players are chosen doesn't matter, so the answer is $$ \binom{10}{3} = \frac{10 \times 9 \times 8}{3 \times 2 \times 1} = \boxed{120}.
 $$
 *)

theorem
fixes n k :: nat and starting_lineup :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "n = 12"
and h1 : "k = 5"
and h2 : "Ace \<in> starting_lineup"
and h3 : "Zeppo \<in> starting_lineup"
and h4 : "card starting_lineup = k"
and h5 : "starting_lineup \<subseteq> {1..n}"
shows  "card {S. S \<subseteq> {1..n} - {Ace, Zeppo} \<and> card S = k - 2} = 120"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: In a sports team, there are 12 players, including Ace and Zeppo. The coach needs to select a starting lineup of 5 players. If Ace and Zeppo are already in the starting lineup, how many different ways can the coach select the remaining 3 players from the 10 other players? The final answer is 120.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes start_lineups :: nat
assumes h0 : "start_lineups = nCr 10 3"
shows  "start_lineups = 120"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Coach Grunt is preparing the 5-person starting lineup for his basketball team, the Grunters.  There are 12 players on the team.  $$
 *)

theorem
fixes start_lineups :: nat
assumes h0 : "start_lineups = nCr 10 3"
shows  "start_lineups = 120"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: How many different starting lineups can be formed by choosing 3 players from a team of 10 players? The final answer is 120.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n k :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 12"
and h1 : "k = 5"
and h2 : "card {Ace, Zeppo} = 2"
and h3 : "finite {Ace, Zeppo}"
shows  "card (set (combinations (n - 2) (k - 2))) = 120"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Coach Grunt is preparing the 5-person starting lineup for his basketball team, the Grunters.  There are 12 players on the team.  Two of them, Ace and Zeppo, are league All-Stars, so they'll definitely be in the starting lineup.  How many different starting lineups are possible?  (The order of the players in a basketball lineup doesn't matter.) The final Answer is 120
 ### Proof
 Coach Grunt has to choose 3 players from the 10 players that are remaining after Ace and Zeppo have been placed in the lineup. The order in which the players are chosen doesn't matter, so the answer is $$ \binom{10}{3} = \frac{10 \times 9 \times 8}{3 \times 2 \times 1} = \boxed{120}.
 $$
 *)

theorem
fixes n k :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 12"
and h1 : "k = 5"
and h2 : "card {Ace, Zeppo} = 2"
and h3 : "finite {Ace, Zeppo}"
shows  "card (set (combinations (n - 2) (k - 2))) = 120"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Given a set with 12 elements (including "Ace" and "Zeppo"), find the number of combinations of 5 elements where "Ace" and "Zeppo" are always included. The final answer is 120.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n k ace_zeppo :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 12"
and h1 : "k = 5"
and h2 : "ace_zeppo = 2"
and h3 : "\<forall> lineup. size lineup = k \<and> Ace \<in> lineup \<and> Zeppo \<in> lineup \<longrightarrow> (n - ace_zeppo) choose (k - ace_zeppo) different starting lineups"
shows  "different starting lineups = 120"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Coach Grunt is preparing the 5-person starting lineup for his basketball team, the Grunters.  There are 12 players on the team.  Two of them, Ace and Zeppo, are league All-Stars, so they'll definitely be in the starting lineup.  How many different starting lineups are possible?  (The order of the players in a basketball lineup doesn't matter.) The final Answer is 120
 ### Proof
 Coach Grunt has to choose 3 players from the 10 players that are remaining after Ace and Zeppo have been placed in the lineup. The order in which the players are chosen doesn't matter, so the answer is $$ \binom{10}{3} = \frac{10 \times 9 \times 8}{3 \times 2 \times 1} = \boxed{120}.
 $$
 *)

theorem
fixes n k ace_zeppo :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 12"
and h1 : "k = 5"
and h2 : "ace_zeppo = 2"
and h3 : "\<forall> lineup. size lineup = k \<and> Ace \<in> lineup \<and> Zeppo \<in> lineup \<longrightarrow> (n - ace_zeppo) choose (k - ace_zeppo) different starting lineups"
shows  "different starting lineups = 120"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: There are 12 players on a team, including Ace and Zeppo. The team needs to choose a starting lineup of 5 players. If Ace and Zeppo are always included in the starting lineup, how many different starting lineups can be formed using the remaining players? The final answer is 120.
